question: My best ideas when fighting evil monsters come from an interchange of ideas and sharing with others.
When planning our next move as Sailor Guardians, I am usually disciplined about following my prepared agenda.
When handling (let's just say Usagi's) development, I am most likely to discuss a problem I have with her behavior.
I prefer our secret lare to be structured with clear rules and regulations.
I would rather work alongside a Moon Princess with whom I have a lot of day-by-day interaction.
I prefer our meetings where most time is spent on the application of the ideas discussed.
I prefer an environment where frequent differences of opinion breed interesting discussions and ideas.
I prefer projects and our dangerous missions to be well-defined and planned out.
I prefer to spend my lunch hour eating with the other sailor scouts.
When faced with a difficult task, I usually collect as much information as possible before heading into battle.
In a performance appraisal, I'd prefer Luna and Artemis to write that I am intelligent and reasonable.
I prefer to plan our missions carefully in advance instead of diving in head first.
I more often prefer to keep my door open.
When a new idea flashes into my mind, I usually like to test if carefully before I get excited and tell the other Sailor Scouts.
When talking with my fellow Sailor Scouts, I prefer to emphasize an analytical discussion of the facts.
I prefer a mission in which the rewards are seen clearly.
I dress each day so that other people notice and admire my clothing (and me).
When I solve problems, I am more likely to give most weight to the facts in front of me.
If I have to confront my fellow scouts, I am usually interested in making sure I give them the facts accurately.
I would rather follow a leader who provides a lot of structure and organization.
I prefer most of my missions to be a continuing series of short tasks.
When I write a report, I usually think first of the details instead of just going with the flow.
When I have a decision to make, I usually reason it through regardless of my feelings.
I prefer to be one in my own area in which things are olderly, organized, and systematic.
I would rather have my fellow sailor scouts trust me with practical problems to solve.
When faced with a hard decision, I usually prefer to think things through.
I prefer our missions while protecting Earth to be continuous and relatively predictable.
When I have to organize and run a sailor scout meeting, I more often feel satisfied that I have the opportunity to lead.
If I were asked to prepare a strategic plan, I would be more likely to emphasize what is practical now.
When faced with a decision, I usually focus on the facts and figures above all.
When given a mission, I usually prefer a clear statement of what is expected.
I prefer to work alongside a large group of sailor guardians during our missions.
When talking one-on-one, I am more likely to listen quietly and absorb details.
If someone argues with a decision I make, I usually remain firm.
When I have made a tough choice, I usually am satisfied that it is done.
When I attend a outing with friends, I usually walk around and meet people I may not know well.
I think my fellow sailor scouts see me more as a here-and-now person.
When I have long and complex information to read, I am more likely to be patient and study the details.
I prefer my environment to be comfortable, predictable, and stable.
My fellow scouts are more likely to describe me as  an energetic team player.
When I prepare a presentation, I prefer to emphasize the use of real facts from my own experience.
I prefer to hang with those who rely heavily on logic.
If a fellow sailor scout is late with a task or to a mission, I usually get impatient and annoyed.
When training my skills, I am more likely to participate openly and actively.
When any of the scouts present ideas to me, I am usually more interested in immediately useful ideas.
If I have to deal with a scouts feelings, I prefer to be truthful even if I can't be tactful.
I prefer missions that have a clear ending time when I know they will be finished.
When I have a decision to make, I more often talk it over with a number of my friends before I decide.
I prefer any type of mission where I can use my experience to tackle familiar hurdles instead of being put on the spot.
When I am at a meeting in our secret lare and a difference of opinion gets heated, I usually defend the side I think is most logical.
When something comes up, I usually prefer to get to it and complete it as quickly as possible instead of procrastinating.
I am more interested in the actual things I am doing day-by-day.
When I attend sailor guardian training, I usually prefer experiential processes.
When I have a meeting with my friends and fellow scouts, I usually get through it quickly in a businesslike manner. It's buisness, not personal
I like engaging in activities requiring me to reach a conclusion.
When I ask a friend for advice or help, I am usually comfortable.
In a meeting about a mission, I am more likely to remember the facts presented.
When my fellow scouts ask my advice about a matter, I more often guide them toward a decision based purely on logic.
I like getting a job done as quickly as possible.
When I am interrupted in the middle of doing something difficult, I usually welcome the opportunity to talk to someone. (Procrastination helps right?)
When I read something informative, I usually go first to the body of detailed information.
When I am putting forward a new idea at among my fellow scouts, I more often remain firm about the correctness of it.
I feel satisfied when I am organized.
When someone tells a joke, I usually laugh and think of one to tell.
It would be more accurate to state I was practical.
I am usually more interested in how my fellow sailor scouts think about problems.
I am usually annoyed or otherwise upset when a change happens.
When having a sailor meeting, I usually speak out directly when I want to.
I like step-by-step plan early in the process when starting something new.
I am more likely to be openly and intellectually critical in response to things.
I prefer to work alongside scots who are well-organized.
I like an open and active environment where I can engage with everyone.
I more often seek out things that apply my practical skills and nature.
When I have to make a decision, I am more likely to analyze the situation logically without considering my values and feelings.
When I present my views, I am usually decisive.
When I need to pass on an idea or information, I prefer to talk directly to people about it.
When leading in anything my leadership style is best described as practical.
I am usually more likely to be frank and honest regardless of feelings.
When I am discussing an important issue, I usually try to reach a definite conclusion quickly.
I enjoy a day filled with variety and interactions with others.
I prefer situations that are stable with little change.
My fellow scouts are more likely to describe my behavior as cool, calm, and objective.
I prefer projects and tasks that involve a short deadline.
I usually greet the person in a comfortable and friendly way.
When I think of my personal assets, they are more in the realm of the practical.
I prefer to use an approach that relies on both precision and logic.
I usually push my fellow sailor scouts to make quick decisions.
